notes:
1. Energy Transfer by Heat ($Q$)

Heat is energy transferred between a system and its surroundings due to a temperature difference. It always flows from higher to lower temperature.

  • Adiabatic Process: A process with zero heat transfer ($Q=0$).

2. Energy Transfer by Work ($W$)

Work is energy transfer associated with a force acting through a distance. In thermodynamics, work is energy transfer across the system boundary that is not caused by a temperature difference.

  • Boundary Work ($W_b$): Work done by the expansion or compression of a fluid (moving boundary). $W_b = \int P dV$.
  • Shaft Work ($W_{sh}$): Energy transmitted by a rotating shaft (e.g., in a turbine or compressor). Power $\dot{W}_{sh} = 2\pi \dot{n} T$.
  • Electrical Work ($W_e$): Energy transferred by electrons crossing the system boundary. $\dot{W}_e = VI$.

3. Flow Work

In open systems (control volumes), energy is required to push mass into or out of the control volume. This is called flow work or flow energy.

$$ W_{flow} = PV $$

This term is combined with internal energy ($U$) to define enthalpy ($H = U + PV$), which simplifies the analysis of open systems.

solvedExamples.question: A gas expands against a piston in a cylinder from $V_1 = 0.02 \text{ m}^3$ to $V_2 = 0.10 \text{ m}^3$ while the pressure remains constant at 200 kPa. How much boundary work is done by the gas?
solvedExamples.explanation: For a constant pressure (isobaric) process, the work is $W_b = P(V_2 - V_1)$. $W_b = (200 \text{ kPa})(0.10 - 0.02 \text{ m}^3) = 200(0.08) = 16 \text{ kJ}$.

solvedExamples.question: Which form of energy transfer is associated with the motion of a rotating shaft crossing the system boundary?
solvedExamples.explanation: Shaft work is the energy transfer associated with the torque and rotational motion of a shaft, commonly seen in engines, turbines, and pumps.
